source.absolute_timeline_notes: Nighttime dice game in the Wildebeest spans into following nights; immediate aftermath of leadership tensions around Quincy/Robyn/Gavin.

text_windows.full_scene_clean: The dice rattled in the pan like bones as Quincy played Even-Odds in the Wildebeest, drinking puro but emotionally absent. Andreu tried to keep her steady. Gavin staggered in drunk, taunting Quincy about Robyn and declaring Mama Valorie had ended his arrangement with Robyn. He demanded a wager: just him and Quincy, one roll each—if he won, Quincy and Robyn were finished; if she won, he would leave them alone forever. Despite friends restraining her, Quincy, raw with grief and rage, drank on the pact and accepted. Gavin rolled first: fourteen. Quincy, nauseated and shaking, rolled and beat him by one. Gavin exploded, flipping a chair and storming into the night. Quincy’s victory felt hollow; shame and doubt crowded out relief as the players drifted away and she stumbled into the cool dark, fearing what Robyn would think of a future staked on dice.
text_windows.dense_recap_250w: In the Wildebeest livestock trailer, Quincy sits through a late-night Even-Odds dice game to keep a low profile after recent tensions. Gavin, drunk and hostile, barges in, announces that Mama Valorie has broken off his pairing with Robyn, and goads Quincy with accusations that she didn’t fight for Robyn. He escalates to a high-stakes challenge: a single roll-off between the two of them. If he wins, Quincy must end things with Robyn; if she wins, he will leave them alone. Andreu warns Quincy not to engage, but provoked and exhausted, she seals the pact with a shared shot of puro. Gavin rolls a fourteen (4,5,5). Quincy, rattled by the possibility of losing Robyn on a gambler’s bet, throws and edges him by one. Gavin erupts—chair slams, the milk stool and rolling pan tumble—and he storms out. The room freezes, then empties. Quincy’s ‘win’ resolves the immediate threat but leaves her sick with shame for risking her relationship and community standing on a drunken wager. The scene crystallizes intersecting pressures: personal love versus public provocation, self-control versus rage, and the caravan’s social games as both refuge and flashpoint.

embedding_payloads.text: During a tense late-night Even-Odds game in the Wildebeest, Gavin barges in drunk and taunts Quincy about Robyn, citing Mama Valorie’s intervention. He demands a one-roll wager to decide Robyn’s future: his win ends Quincy and Robyn; her win forces him to leave them alone. Despite Andreu’s pleas, Quincy drinks on the pact and accepts. Gavin rolls fourteen; Quincy edges him by one. He flips furniture and storms out. Quincy’s victory feels hollow, and she leaves in shame, fearing the social and personal fallout.

Actors: Quincy (POV, lover of Robyn, provoked into a bet), Gavin (drunk antagonist), Andreu (friend mediator), offstage Robyn and Mama Valorie. Items: Even-Odds dice/pan, holocreds, jug of puro, milk stool, folding chair. Setting: The Wildebeest livestock trailer at night within the Three Shovels Caravan. Dynamics: person-vs-person taunts escalate into a public wager; chance (dice) temporarily overrides authority; community witnesses and disperses.

Gritty, tense third-person limited around Quincy, with sensory details—dice clatter, puro burn, scraping chairs, flickering lamplight. Themes center on love versus control, pride and provocation, chance versus agency, and communal judgment. Motifs include ritual drinking to seal pacts and the hollow victory of winning at a moral cost.
